org.multigraph
Class DataMeasure

java.lang.Object
  org.multigraph.DataMeasure
Direct Known Subclasses:
DatetimeMeasure, NumberMeasure
public abstract class DataMeasure
extends java.lang.Object

A DataMeasure object stores a "measure" which reprents a (directed) distance along a number line. DataMeasures can be added to DataValues to obtain new DataValues; think of the DataMeasure as representing a displacement of a certain distance (and direction) along the number line.

Multigraph uses DataMeasure instances to represent lengths along an axis, for things like tick mark and label spacing, widths of bars in bar graphs, etc.

The details of correctly measuring a length depend on the data type. For example, the measure of "one month" for the DataValue.Type.DATETIME type is different depending on the month, since different months have different lengths. This abstract superclass exists so that data-type-specific subclasses can implement whatever details are needed for measurements of that data type.

Regardless of the specific underlying data type, every DataMeasure corresponds to a particular real number that can generally be used to represent its length along a real number axis corresponding to its data type. The getRealValue() method returns that number. Note that this number may not exactly represent the length of the measure in all cases (see the comments about months above); it is intended to be the "typical", or most common, length of the measure. If you need to be precise, then you'll have to work with the specific subclass.

Overrides:
toString in class java.lang.Object

firstSpacingLocationAtOrAfter

public abstract DataValue firstSpacingLocationAtOrAfter(DataValue value,
                                                        DataValue alignment)
Return the location of the first "tick" at or after a given value, in a grid of regularly spaced ticks separated by this DataMeasure, and aligned with a given alignment. More precisely, return 
     alignment + k * measure
where measure corresponds to the measure represented by this DataMeasure, and k is the smallest integer (inluding possibly negative integers) such that alignment + k * measure >= value.
